5. The base station of any one of the preceding claims, wherein the computer processor is configured to perform a shallow packet inspection of the data packet, and based on the shallow packet inspection, perform a deep packet inspection of the data packet.

6. The base station of any one of the preceding claims, wherein the shallow packet inspection comprises inspecting an IP header of the data packet, and wherein a deep packet inspection comprises inspecting a payload of the data packet.

7. The base station of any one of the preceding claims, wherein the computer processor comprises a packet inspection processor configured to inspect at least one of a packet header, a packet payload, and metadata associated with the data packet to determine the video frame
of the data packet, and a video frame scheduling processor configured to assign resource blocks for transmitting the one or more data packets based on the detected video frame type.

8. The base station of any one of the preceding claims, wherein the computer processor comprises a video frame scheduling processor configured to assign resource blocks for transmitting the one or more data packets based on the detected video frame type.
9. The base station of claim 8, wherein the video frame scheduling processor is configured to assign greater resources for transmitting an I-frame than for a P-frame in the video bit-stream.
10. The base station of claim 8 or 9, wherein the video frame scheduling processor is configured to assign greater resources for transmitting an I-frame than for a B-frame in the video bit-stream.

11. The base station of any one of the preceding claims, wherein the computer processor comprises a video frame transrating processor configured to determine whether a data packet will be transmitted without modification, transmitted with a reduced bit rate, or removed from the video bit-stream based on the detected video frame type.

12. The base station of claim 11, wherein the video frame transrating processor is configured to transmit all I-frames in the bit-stream without modification and reduce a bit rate of or drop at least one B-frame from the bit-stream.

13. The base station of claim 11 or 12, wherein the video frame transrating processor is configured to transmit all I-frames in the bit-stream without modification and reduce a bit rate for at least one P-frame from the bit-stream.

14. The base station of claim 11, wherein the video frame transrating processor is configured to append information identifying whether a data packet may be removed from the bit-stream, and wherein the computer processor further comprises a video frame scheduling processor configured to schedule the data packet for transmission based on detected radio channel conditions at the base station.

15. A method for coordinating communication of data packets between a user device and an application server utilizing a base station, the data packets corresponding to a bit-stream of encoded video data, the method comprising:
detecting a video frame type of the data packets; and
transmitting one or more of the plurality of data packets based on the detected video frame type.
16. The method of claim 15, comprising assigning resource blocks for transmitting one or more of the plurality of data packets.
17. The method of claim 15 or 16, comprising inspecting data packets and assigning resource blocks to data packets upon arrival at the base station.

18. The method of any one of the preceding claims, comprising transmitting the data packet to a remote radio head, and wherein the remote radio head comprises a radio transmitter and a radio receiver.

19. The method of any one of the preceding claims, comprising performing a shallow packet inspection of the data packet, and based on the shallow packet inspection, performing a deep packet inspection of the data packet.

20. The method of any one of the preceding claims, wherein the shallow packet inspection comprises inspecting an IP header of the data packet, and wherein a deep packet inspection comprises inspecting a payload of the data packet.

21. The method of any one of the preceding claims, comprising determining a radio channel condition and assigning resource blocks for transmitting the one or more data packets based on the detected video frame type.
22. The method of any one of the preceding claims, comprising assigning greater resources for transmitting an I-frame than for a P-frame in the video bit-stream.
23. The method of any one of the preceding claims, comprising assigning greater resources for transmitting an I-frame than for a B-frame in the video bit-stream.

24. The method of any one of the preceding claims, comprising transmitting a data packet without modification, reducing the bit rate of the data packet, or dropping the data packet based on the detected video frame type.

25. The method of any one of the preceding claims, comprising transmitting all I- frames in the bit-stream without modification and reducing the bit rate of or dropping at least one B- frame from the bit-stream.
26. The method of any one of the preceding claims, comprising transmitting all I-frames in the bit-stream without modification and reducing a bit rate of at least one P-frame from the bit-stream.

27. The method of any one of the preceding claims, comprising appending information identifying whether a data packet may be removed from the bit-stream, and scheduling the data packet for transmission based on detected radio channel conditions at the base station.

28. A non-transitory computer readable medium having stored thereon a computer program product that is capable of being executed by computer processing circuitry, the computer program product including instructions for causing the processing circuitry to: detect a video frame type of each of a plurality of data packets in a video bit-stream received by a base station; and
transmit one or more of the plurality of data packets based on the detected video frame type.

29. The non-transitory computer-readable medium of claim 28, wherein the computer program product includes instructions for causing the processing circuitry to transmit a data packet without modification, reduce the bit rate of the data packet, or drop the data packet based on the detected video frame type.

30. The non-transitory computer-readable medium of claim 28 or 29, wherein the computer program product includes instructions for causing the processing circuitry to assign
resource blocks for scheduling the data packets for transmission based on the detected video frame type.
